meta.title: Anatomy E&D - Mission NEET PG 2.0 - Final Batch - 10-06-2025 - 2025-06-10

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with headache, nausea, and double vision. Fundoscopic examination reveals papilledema, and imaging confirms raised intracranial pressure. Which cranial nerve is most commonly affected in this condition?

A 12-year-old boy presents after a fall on his outstretched arm, resulting in pain and swelling around the elbow. Imaging reveals a fracture dislocation of the medial epicondyle. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this scenario?
Which of the following muscles is most essential for performing screwing movements in the upper limb?
With which carpal bone does the pisiform bone articulate?
Which of the following muscles is not typically involved as an accessory muscle of respiration during laboured breathing?
A 55-year-old patient undergoes neck surgery and sustains an injury to the hypoglossal nerve. Which of the following deficits is most likely observed after this injury?

options.label: B
options.text: Deviated tongue to the same side as the injury

options.label: C
options.text: Deviated tongue to the opposite side of the injury

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of taste in the posterior one-third of the tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Deviated tongue to the same side as the injury
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Deviated tongue to the same side as the injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with arm weakness and difficulty lifting objects. On examination, the biceps reflex is diminished. Which nerve root is responsible for this biceps reflex?
At which vertebral level is the fundus of the gallbladder typically located?

A 40-year-old patient presents with a waddling gait and difficulty stabilizing the pelvis while walking. Examination reveals weakness in hip abduction. Damage to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for these findings?

A 35-year-old woman presents with pelvic organ prolapse and stress urinary incontinence. Examination reveals weakened pelvic floor muscles. Which of the following muscle, a part of the levator ani muscle group is responsible for these conditions?
During the assessment of the femoral triangle, which structure forms the lateral boundary of this anatomical region?
Which of the following is not a branch of the basilar artery?

A 35-year-old man presents with a head injury following a motor vehicle collision. Imaging reveals a fracture in the region of the pterion. Which of the following structures is most closely related to the pterion and at risk of injury?

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with symptoms of memory impairment and confusion. MRI reveals damage to the mammillary bodies. Through which structure do these mammillary bodies primarily receive afferent input?

A 17-year-old male sustains a stab injury near the neck and shoulder and presents with an adducted, medially rotated arm, and an extended, pronated forearm hanging by the side. Examination reveals a loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm. Which nerve root is most likely affected?
Portal hypertension is seen in case of cirrhosis. At what vertebral level portal vein is formed?

A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling on his outstretched hand while skateboarding. He complains of pain and swelling around the wrist joint. On examination, there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of the wrist. An X-ray is ordered to assess for any fractures and evaluate the integrity of the wrist joint. As the orthopaedic resident reviews the radiograph, she explains to the medical student the bones involved in forming the wrist (radiocarpal) joint. Based on your understanding of wrist joint anatomy, which of the following bones does not directly contribute to the formation of the wrist (radiocarpal) joint?

A 35-year-old female runner presents to the clinic with acute pain and swelling around her right ankle after twisting it during a trail run. She reports hearing a "pop" followed by immediate difficulty bearing weight. On physical examination, there is swelling around the lateral malleolus and limited range of motion in the ankle. An X-ray is ordered to assess for fractures and to evaluate the integrity of the ankle joint. While reviewing the radiograph with the attending physician, the medical intern is asked. Which of the following bones does not contribute to the formation of the ankle joint?
A 55-year-old man presents with weakness in the lower extremities. Imaging reveals a lesion in the paracentral lobule. Which of the following regions is most likely to be affected?
The arrow in the image corresponds to the intervertebral disc at which thoracic vertebral level?

A 29-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with concerns about infertility after trying to conceive for over a year. She has regular menstrual cycles and no significant past medical history. As part of the fertility workup, a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is performed, which shows that her fallopian tubes are patent. During the discussion, the gynecologist explains the role of the fallopian tubes in transporting the ovum from the ovary to the uterus and highlights the importance of the epithelial lining in this process. To help the medical student understand the physiology, the gynecologist asks: What type of epithelium lines the fallopian tube, aiding in ovum transport?

A 54-year-old woman presents with acute onset of a headache and double vision. Examination reveals ptosis and an enlarged pupil in the left eye. Imaging shows a berry aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery. Which of the following structures is most likely compressed by this aneurysm?
Which part of the inguinal canal is formed by fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles?

A 42-year-old man presents with burning pain and numbness over the lateral aspect of his right thigh. Examination reveals no motor weakness. The condition is caused by compression of which of the following nerves?

A 27-year-old athlete presents with difficulty walking after an ankle sprain. Examination reveals weakness in foot eversion. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for eversion of the foot?

A 47-year-old patient is undergoing imaging to evaluate a suspected diaphragmatic hernia. During the study, you are asked to identify which structure passes through the vena caval opening at the T8 vertebral level. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a concern about a "visible vein" in his right shoulder area. He reports that the vein becomes more pronounced during exercise or when lifting heavy objects. There is no associated pain, redness, or swelling. He denies any history of trauma to the area. On inspection of the right shoulder area reveals a prominent, non-pulsatile, linear structure running along the deltopectoral groove is seen. Which of the following structure is seen in this area?

A daily wage worker who carries loads, experienced great difficulty in raising his left arm above his head. The physician asked the patient to press his hands against the wall in front. While doing so, the medial border and inferior angle of his left scapula became prominent. Which of the following statements is correct concerning this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower fibres of serratus anterior causes glenoid cavity to turn downward

options.label: B
options.text: Actions of serratus anterior is antagonized by contraction of rhomboids and middle fibres of trapezius

options.label: C
options.text: Serratus anterior is supplied by Lateral pectoral nerve

options.label: D
options.text: First digitation of serratus anterior is seen in the anterior triangle of neck

questions.correct_answer: B. Actions of serratus anterior is antagonized by contraction of rhomboids and middle fibres of trapezius
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Actions of serratus anterior is antagonized by contraction of rhomboids and middle fibres of trapezius

questions.text: A group of medical students are learning about the femoral sheath and its contents during a clinical skills session. They are asked to identify the structures contained within the femoral sheath. Which of the following options correctly lists the contents of the femoral sheath?

options.label: A
options.text: Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein, Femoral Nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein, Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

options.label: C
options.text: Femoral Artery, Femoral Nerve, Lymphatic Vessels

options.label: D
options.text: Femoral Vein, Femoral Nerve, Lymphatic Vessels

questions.correct_answer: B. Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein, Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein, Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with complaints of recurrent swelling on one side of neck, pain while eating and subsides after a few hours. Imaging performed shows a sialolith. The postganglionic secretomotor fibres for the involved salivary gland is from:

A 62-year-old male presents with unsteady gait and difficulty with coordination on the right side of his body. Neurological examination reveals intention tremor, dysmetria, and impaired rapid alternating movements. An MRI of the brain is ordered, which reveals a lesion affecting the lateral hemisphere of the right cerebellum. While reviewing the case, the neurologist discusses the deep cerebellar nuclei involved in motor coordination and their anatomical locations with a group of medical students. To assess understanding, the neurologist asks: Which of the following cerebellar nuclei is the most laterally located?
Which of the following structures passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm?

A 55-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease presents with worsening chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. The patient is taken to the catheterization lab for urgent coronary angiography. During the procedure, the cardiologist is concerned about the anatomical relationships surrounding the heart. Which of the following structures is most likely to be found anterior to the transverse pericardial sinus in this patient?
The tissue in the image is found in -

A 32-year-old female presents with pain and tenderness over the right clavicle. Physical examination reveals localized swelling and crepitus upon palpation. Radiological imaging shows a midshaft clavicle fracture. Which anatomical structure is most affected in this type of fracture?
questions.correct_answer: D. Middle third of the clavicle
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Middle third of the clavicle

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the marked structure is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is example of pressure epiphysis.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives attachment to long head of humerus and coracobrachialis.

options.label: C
options.text: It is palpable in delto-pectoral groove.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not palpable in infraclavicular fossa even in thin built persons.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is palpable in delto-pectoral groove.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) It is palpable in delto-pectoral groove.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical statements are true Congenital absence of pectoralis major is known as Poland syndrome. Due to damage of Bell’s nerve (long thoracic nerve) winging of scapula occurs. Congenital high scapula is also known as Springles deformity In Cleidocranial dysostosis clavicle is absent and shoulders can be approximated

A 42-year-old software engineer presents to the clinic complaining of chronic neck pain and stiffness. The pain is localized on the back and side of the neck and sometimes radiates to the shoulder. The patient reports that the pain worsens after long periods of working on the computer. Physical examination reveals tenderness and tightness in the upper neck region. Pain is particularly exacerbated by rotating the head to the opposite side and tilting it downwards. Marked muscles is most likely involved in this patient's condition. What is the nerve supply of this muscle?

options.label: C
options.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain radiating to the right arm, which started while he was gardening. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads. Coronary angiography is likely to show occlusion of right coronary artery. All of the following are true about this artery except:

options.label: A
options.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery

options.label: B
options.text: It arises from the anterior aortic sinus

options.label: C
options.text: It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

options.label: D
options.text: Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.correct_answer: C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
questions.explanation: Ans. C) It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

questions.text: Which of these is not a type of synovial joint?

A 45-year-old man presents with sudden severe chest pain. He has a history of hypertension, and you suspect aortic dissection. An urgent CT scan shows a widened aorta with a false lumen but no obvious signs of rupture. You note to your consultant that the dissection extends to the level of the aortic opening of the diaphragm, and express your concern about possible damage to all the structures that pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. These structures include all of the following except:
What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?

Following surgery for varicose veins, the patient is experiencing a complaint of sensory loss in the medial area of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is the most probable site of injury?
Identify the cartilage shown below:
During a yawn, a student experienced a jaw locking incident. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except:
Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum:

A 40-year-old male patient was admitted with complaints of acute pain in the right shoulder of three-days duration associated with swelling and he also had difficulty in using his right shoulder since then. Pain was sudden at onset, continuous, and moderate to severe in intensity and it was aggravated on activity. In addition, he had severe night and rest pain. He also gave a history of intramuscular injection of Iron in the right deltoid region 2 weeks previously, which was administered in a local clinic. On examination, there was a globular swelling in the lateral aspect of the right arm extending up to the scapular region. There was a local rise of temperature and tenderness over the swelling, painful restriction of the right shoulder movements and he could not abduct his arm to the right angle. MRI scan of the right shoulder showed pyomyositis of the posterior belly of the right deltoid muscle with central abscess formation. Which among the following is not a possible complication that can be expected in this case if untreated?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm

options.label: C
options.text: Weak of flexion of arm at shoulder joint

options.label: D
options.text: Inability to extend the arm at shoulder joint

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm

questions.text: Injury to the nerve that lies laterally to the structure pointed will result in?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of taste sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of secretion from parotid gland

questions.correct_answer: D. Loss of secretion from parotid gland
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Loss of secretion from parotid gland

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
Identify the papillae from the given histological section:
Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?

options.label: A
options.text: The flexing of the arm with respect to the forearm around the elbow.

options.label: B
options.text: The elevation of the foot to the medial and lateral directions.

options.label: C
options.text: The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless.

options.label: D
options.text: The rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a cone shape.

questions.correct_answer: C. The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of weakness in his right arm after using crutches for six weeks due to a leg fracture. He mentions that the crutches were possibly too tall for him, as they pressed hard into his armpit. On examination, there is a notable deficit in the extension of his wrist and fingers, and he has difficulty with thumb abduction. His sense of touch is diminished over the posterior aspect of his arm and forearm and the dorsum of his hand. Given the distribution of his symptoms, which structure is most likely to be affected by the prolonged use of crutches?

A 36-year-old auto driver was attacked by a mob over a family quarrel and received a stab wound at the front of the neck. He was rushed to the emergency department. The knife entrance wound was located on the right side of the neck just lateral to the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone. During the physical examination the patient was asked to protrude his tongue, which deviated to the right. Which of the following statements would is incorrect regarding the physical signs in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Paralysis of the right genioglossus muscle permitted the left genioglossus to pull the tongue forward and turned the tip to the right side

options.label: B
options.text: Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

options.label: C
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve descends in the neck between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.

options.label: D
options.text: At about the level of the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone the hypoglossal nerve turns forward and crosses the internal and external carotid arteries and the lingual artery to enter the tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured?

A 42-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department following a workplace accident. He reports a fall from a height, landing awkwardly on his right leg. The patient complains of severe pain and weakness in the lower limb, particularly on the lateral side of his right leg. On examination, there is noticeable foot drop with decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot and the lateral leg. Which nerve injury is most likely responsible for the observed symptoms of foot drop and sensory deficit in this patient's right lower limb?

A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of progressive weakness in his right leg. He reports difficulty in climbing stairs and rising from a seated position. During examination, the patient demonstrates noticeable weakness in his right hip joint movement against resistance. Additionally, there is reduced ability to extend his right thigh while lying prone. Which nerve is involvement in supplying the chief extensor of the thigh at the hip joint might correspond to the observed weakness and limitations in this patient's right leg?

Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? 1. Superior gluteal artery 2. Inferior gluteal artery 3. Superior vesical artery 4. Middle rectal artery 5. Inferior vesical artery 6. Vaginal artery

A patient Vinod, who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. A nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?

The marked structures in image are a pair of small, round nuclei located on the undersurface of the brain. They form part of the limbic system and are involved in memory processing and recall. Damage to it is commonly associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, typically seen in chronic alcoholics and characterized by confabulation, memory impairment, and ataxia. These structures receive signals from the hippocampus via the fornix and project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in the Papez circuit, which is important for emotional expression and memory consolidation. Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?

A 75 year old male presented with history of frequency, hesitancy & urgency for urination. He was on medication of Tamsulosin & Finasteride combination. Now Trans Urethral Resection of Prostate (TURP) surgery was recommended by physician. What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males?
Which structure from the options given below is supplied by the nerve that arises from the marked area in the image?

The Anesthetist’s artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, is a key vessel responsible for supplying blood to the lower region of the face, including the lips, chin, and cheeks. It courses deep to the submandibular gland, then winds its way along the mandible's lower border, eventually curving up over the mandible at the anteroinferior angle of the masseter muscle. This artery is palpable at the mandibular border and is clinically significant due to its proximity to facial structures and potential involvement in facial surgeries and trauma. Moreover, its pulsation can be an important diagnostic point in physical examinations, particularly in assessing blood flow in the facial region. Which is not a branch of this artery?
Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?

A young man presenting with features of recurrent brief depressive disorder, each lasting for about 3 to 7 days, for over a year. He had history of occasional headache and episodes of swooning attack in between, usually precipitated by emotional events. His neuroimaging revealed agenesis of corpus callosum. He was experiencing swooning attacks as he became aware that some ‘unusual’ findings were present in his reports. Recurrent brief depression can be a manifestation of this congenital anomaly, and conversion disorder can be present as comorbid diagnosis perhaps due to ignorance and fear of this apparently innocuous congenital malformation. What is blood supply of corpus callosum?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

options.label: D
options.text: Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the orthopaedic clinic with persistent discomfort and swelling in his right knee. He reports a history of recurrent pain and limited knee movement that worsens during prolonged periods of walking or climbing stairs. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling noted at the posterior aspect of the right knee joint, particularly on the lateral side. Which structure's potential presence, resembling a sesamoid bone, might contribute to the observed discomfort and swelling in the posterior aspect of this patient's right knee?

A 67 year old lady Janki, presented with loss of subconscious kinaesthetic sensation, loss of pain and temperature sensation as well as loss of crude touch from body. On examination fine touch sensation was found normal. In case of spinal angiography blockage of which of the following artery might be seen?

A 40 years old female Vimla, presented with road traffic accident with brief loss of consciousness. Fatigue, pallor and weakness on general examination. She was also having mild jaundice and gall stones. Massive hepatosplenomegaly with hypersplenism was also found. On skull radiography widening of diploic spaces was found. On previous history she was reported to have failure to thrive in early childhood, growth retardation, and delayed puberty. Other findings are leg ulcer and skin bronzing. After the RTA she is having headache and also presenting with lucid interval, nausea, vomiting focal neurological deficits. On plain X ray skull fracture is visible and on CT scan hyperdense biconvex opacity is visible on temporal region. What is your single best diagnosis for current presentation?

A patient Ramlal, 56 years old male, presented with history of palanaesthesia, astereognosis, loss of proprioception and fine touch sensation. He has chronic history of smoking, diabetes and hypertension. In case of spinal angiography blockage of which of the following artery might be seen?

A 50-year male Jagan, was presented with severe headache and vomiting and history of immediate unconsciousness immediately. On admission he was found hypertensive and history of poorly controlled hypertension also found. Gradual decline in neurological functions was present. Neck stiffness, Kernig’s sign was also found positive. NCCT was done but it failed to make a diagnosis. Then LP was performed in which CSF was found grossly bloody with RBC counts upto 1 million/cu mm. After 48 hours of clinical manifestations xanthochromic spinal fluid was found. What is your single best diagnosis?

A 35 years old alcoholic and chronic smoker male Amit, was having the history of hypercholesterolemia for 8 years. He presented at OPD with hemiplegia on right side of body. On examination he was having loss of proprioception, fine touch and vibration sensations on right side. He was also unable to recognize the objects with closed eyes from right hand. On examination left side of the tongue was atrophied and deviation on left side during protrusion was found. On cerebral angiography there was blockage of artery located in median fissure of spinal cord at lower part of brain stem was found. What is your diagnosis?
Superior, inferior & facial colliculus are indicated respectively as?
Identify the nerve root(s) of the thickened nerve marked in the arrow in the image shown below:

Vidian neurectomy is a surgical procedure targeting the vidian nerve to treat severe chronic rhinitis unresponsive to medical therapy. It effectively reduces symptoms like nasal congestion and excessive discharge but carries risks such as dry eyes and altered taste sensation. This surgery is reserved for carefully selected patients where benefits outweigh potential complications. Which nerve is cut in Vidian’s Neurectomy ?
Blockage of artery supplying to indicate area will cause all except:
